https://prez.dev/description.@value: A categorization of disciplines or topics that the broad field of Earth science can be subdivided into, i.e. a listing of the Fields of Research, or subjects, to which a geoscience dataset, publication, observation/activity, or entity pertains. The vocabulary also contains relevant disciplines that intersect with the various Earth science fields, such as biological sciences and built environment and design, as well as entries related to collection and heritage management. Notations included are those from the 2020 ANZSRC listing (see History Note) or in common use in the geoscience community.

https://prez.dev/label.@value: computational modelling and simulation in earth sciences

https://prez.dev/description.@value: A multidisciplinary field that combines geoscience with advanced mathematical modelling, simulation, numerical modelling, visualization and data analysis techniques. Computational geoscience uses large-scale, nonlinear models that couple multiple physical, chemical, and biological processes across various length and time scales to improve our understanding of the Earth system and its complexities, addressing geoscience grand challenges, and providing decision-support tools for geoscience policy makers and industry. The emergence of computation as a powerful tool for prediction and decision-making in the geosciences is driven by advances in the rapid expansion of our ability to instrument and observe the Earth, sustained improvements in computational models and solution methods for complex geoscience systems, and the relentless growth in computing power.

Earth and Space Science Informatics (ESSI) encompasses a broad field that addresses data management practices, computation and analysis, and hardware and software infrastructure. It involves collaborative work to assess, design, implement, and promote practices and tools that enable effective data management, discovery, integration, and reuse for interdisciplinary work in Earth and space science (ESS) disciplines.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The application of modern information technology/computational systems to organize, preserve, and distribute geoscience data, and to facilitate and advance their analysis, i.e. the science and technology that develop and use data, software, and computing facilities in the cyberinfrastructure ecosystem to address the needs of geosciences and related branches of science and engineering.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition, revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011) and Wikipedia.

https://prez.dev/description.@value: The application of modern information technology/computational systems to organize, preserve, and distribute geoscience data, and to facilitate and advance their analysis, i.e. the science and technology that develop and use data, software, and computing facilities in the cyberinfrastructure ecosystem to address the needs of geosciences and related branches of science and engineering.
Geoinformatics data and information not otherwise described by other sub-categories of geoinformatics.
The developing of tools that promote geoscience data integration and synthesis, and also facilitate quantitative cross-disciplinary access to data.
